ARTS-6567.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6567.courseDescription: examines selections from the works of the Greek "lovers of wisdom" - the first philosophers - particularly Plato.

ARTS-6550.courseDescription: is a survey of the development of Western philosophy since the 17th century.
ARTS-6550.CR: the former PHIL 3700, the former PHIL 3701

ARTS-6551.PR: PHIL 1200 and PHIL 2210 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6551.courseDescription: examines techniques and topics in the logic of propositions, of predicates and of induction and probability. Normally the second course in logic.

ARTS-6557.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6557.courseDescription: examines leading philosophical ideas concerning the origin and justification of political institutions.

ARTS-6554.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6554.courseDescription: investigates various uses of language and its relationship to thought, as well as particular features of language, such as meaning, synonymy, reference, translation and interpretation.

ARTS-6555.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6555.courseDescription: examines major issues in the origins, methods and philosophical implications of science. Science as a form of knowledge; its relation to metaphysics; to more general theories of knowledge. Science and values.

ARTS-6601.courseTitle: Seminar in the Philosophy of Science

ARTS-6558.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department

ARTS-6559.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6559.courseDescription: examines the expression and interpretation in the humanistic disciplines: theology, history, art and literature, language.

ARTS-6619.courseDescription: is a part-time, one semester period of practical work designed to provide experience in medical, psychiatric, environmental, or other similar settings. Students may be placed, e.g., in a government policy office or a hospital.
ARTS-6619.courseTitle: Instructional Field Placement in Applied Ethics
ARTS-6619.UL: applicable only towards the Diploma in Applied Ethics

ARTS-6594.courseDescription: examines the philosophy and literature of Existentialism from Kierkegaard, Nietzsche and Dostoevsky to Sartre, de Beauvoir and Camus.

ARTS-6605.courseDescription: topics will be announced by the Department.

ARTS-6592.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6592.courseDescription: is an introduction to the philosophy of Husserl and some of his followers, e.g. Heidegger, Merleau-Ponty.

ARTS-6593.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6593.courseDescription: examines the pragmatist standpoint from Peirce to the present.

ARTS-6591.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6591.courseDescription: examines selections from established texts in contemporary analytic philosophy: Russell, Carnap, Wittgenstein and others.

ARTS-6611.courseTitle: Seminar in the Philosophy of Language

ARTS-6578.courseDescription: is an introduction to the work of one of the most influential thinkers of the modern era, concentrating on his theory of knowledge, particularly as stated in the

ARTS-6616.PR: 6 credit hours in courses at the 3000 level or permission of the Department
ARTS-6616.courseDescription: is an individualized course tailored to the specialized moral interests of each student.

ARTS-6615.PR: 6 credit hours in courses at the 3000 level or permission of the Department
ARTS-6615.courseDescription: topics will be announced by the Department.
ARTS-6615.courseTitle: Seminar in Twentieth- and Twenty-First Century Philosophy

ARTS-6579.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6579.courseDescription: is an introduction to the work of one of the most influential thinkers of the modern era, concentrating on his ethics, particularly as stated in

ARTS-6610.courseTitle: Seminar in Philosophical Background to Literature

ARTS-6541.courseDescription: examines concepts of health and illness and their ethical implications.

ARTS-6540.courseDescription: will examine Western theories and practices of soul-care which parallel and resonate with Eastern approaches. We will learn what is distinctive to Western approaches with selections from Socrates, Jesus, Paul, Plotinus, Augustine, Eckhart, Alchemy, Freud, Jung and Foucault. Students will not only gain knowledge of this lost road in Western culture, but also an understanding of themselves.

ARTS-6543.courseDescription: examines medical dilemmas from legal and ethical points of view.

ARTS-6542.courseDescription: examines concepts of mental health and illness and their ethical implications.

ARTS-6545.courseDescription: examines concepts of technology and their ethical implications.

ARTS-6544.courseDescription: examines concepts of nature and their ethical implications.

ARTS-6547.courseDescription: examines ethical issues and dilemmas arising in the realm of the mass media, within the context of foundational ethical theories and major philosophies of mass communication. Topics include the nature and structure of mass communication, the public sphere, and the role of the media in a functioning democracy. Subtopics include: propaganda, censorship, freedom of speech, and access to information and communication.

ARTS-6546.courseDescription: introduces some of the central philosophers, topics and themes in the philosophy of film. Topics and themes include: the nature of film image, the relationship between film and “reality”, the social/ political role and function of film and the nature and value of the documentary. The course will also consider the representation of broader philosophical ideas in film. A film or films will accompany each section.

ARTS-6603.courseTitle: Seminar in the Philosophy of Mind

ARTS-6618.PR: 6 credit hours in courses at the 3000 level or permission of the Department
ARTS-6618.courseDescription: is part of the Honours program.

ARTS-6569.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department

ARTS-6568.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6568.courseDescription: examines the works and legacy of perhaps the most influential systematic thinker of all time.

ARTS-6585.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6585.courseDescription: examines 19th century reactions to idealist systems, the critique of Metaphysics, the rise of Positivism.

ARTS-6584.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6584.courseDescription: examines moral, political and jurisprudential themes in Bentham, J.S. Mill and their followers. Recent utilitarian theories.

ARTS-6586.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6586.courseDescription: examines the political, social and historical theories of Marx and Engels and their later developments; themes in Marxist analysis of class and capitalism.

ARTS-6583.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6583.courseDescription: examines selections from Hegel's system with emphasis on the nature of dialectical and speculative philosophy and its enormous influence in the present time.

ARTS-6617.PR: 6 credit hours in courses at the 3000 level or permission of the Department
ARTS-6617.courseDescription: is part of the Honours program.

ARTS-6574.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6574.courseDescription: is a systematic introduction to the works and thought of the "father of modern philosophy".

ARTS-6600.courseTitle: Seminar in Logic and the Philosophy of Mathematics

ARTS-6575.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6575.courseDescription: is a study of rationalism in Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz and of subsequent developments of this standpoint.

ARTS-6534.courseDescription: is an introduction to traditional and modern logic. Open in any year to all students wishing acquaintance with basic logical skills.

ARTS-6535.courseDescription: examines various concepts of knowledge - empirical, rational, transcendental, systematic. Their metaphysical grounds and implications. The concept of scientific knowledge; real and abstract entities; objectivity and subjectivity.

ARTS-6536.courseDescription: examines the sources and validity of ethical principles which underlie individual and social action.

ARTS-6537.CR: Linguistics 2300 , the former Linguistics 2710, the former PHIL 2710

ARTS-6530.courseDescription: is an approach to philosophical thinking by way of analysis and critique of theories of human nature, classical and modern, and the world views associated with them. Philosophy 1000, or the former Philosophy 1600, is not required for further courses in philosophy but is of particular value to students interested in the Social Sciences and Humanities. All sections of this course will qualify as a Research/Writing course for the B.A.
ARTS-6530.CR: the former PHIL 1001, the former PHIL 1600

ARTS-6531.courseDescription: aims to impart critical analytic skills: i.e., the ability to recognize good and bad arguments, to explain why a particular argument is good or bad, and a general understanding of why a good argument ought to persuade and a bad argument ought not to persuade.

ARTS-6532.courseDescription: is a general introduction to the study of Philosophy both as a contemporary intellectual discipline and as a body of knowledge. The course covers the main divisions, fundamental questions and essential terminology of Philosophy through a reading of classical texts. It is a prerequisite for courses at the 3000 level or above in Philosophy programs. It is intended for students in first year who have completed one semester of university education. All sections of this course will qualify as a Research/Writing course for the B.A.

ARTS-6533.courseDescription: is an introduction to the systematic inquiry into the nature of reality. Topic may include the nature of being, time, the question of God, appearance and reality, the one and the many, mind and matter, essence and existence.

ARTS-6614.PR: 6 credit hours in courses at the 3000 level or permission of the Department
ARTS-6614.courseDescription: will be announced by the Department.
ARTS-6614.courseTitle: Seminar in Special Authors and Texts

ARTS-6612.courseTitle: Seminar in the Philosophy of Language

ARTS-6538.courseDescription: employs historical and contemporary sources to explore major traditions and concepts in the philosophy of law. Topics covered include natural law, legal positivism, the nature of legal interpretation, the relationship between law and morality, and the concepts of rights, responsibility, and justice.

ARTS-6539.courseDescription: discusses the philosophical dimensions of an area of practical concern such as contemporary culture, professional ethics, leisure, education, the mass media, gender, war and human rights.

ARTS-6577.PR: PHIL 1200 or permission of the Department
ARTS-6577.courseDescription: is a study of the work and influence of Hume on theories of knowledge, metaphysics and moral philosophy.
